review.title: Argudas: arguing with gene expression information
review.abstract: In situ hybridisation gene expression information helps biologists identify where a gene is expressed. However, the databases that republish the experimental information are often both incomplete and inconsistent. This paper examines a system, Argudas, designed to help tackle these issues. Argudas is an evolution of an existing system, and so that system is reviewed as a means of both explaining and justifying the behaviour of Argudas. Throughout the discussion of Argudas a number of issues will be raised including the appropriateness of argumentation in biology and the challenges faced when integrating apparently similar online biological databases.

sections.heading: 5 Future work
sections.text: This work aims to model expert knowledge and bring it to reason with information sources available on the Internet. However, in the current use case, this use case is relatively limited and therefore limited: it focuses on one type of gene expression information for a model organism. Extending the use case to various types of biological information, such as gene-regulating networks, makes the use case considerably more complex. As the complexity of biological investigation increases, the need for user support also increases. The reasoning is a possible support mechanism. Another possibility for future work refers to CUBIST, Combing and Uniting Business Intelligence with Semantic Technologies, an EU FP7 project, which aims to combine the essential features of Semantic Technologies, Business Intelligence and Visual Analytics. Although data from unstructured and structured sources can be combined within a concept of Business Intelligence with Semantic Technologies, three application techniques of the Expression 7 project are referred to as "Visual Techniques One."

sections.text: This paper describes the reasons for the creation of an argumentation tool (argudas) to tackle the inconsistency and incompleteness in situ hybridization of gene expression resources for the developmental mouse. Furthermore, it discusses the development of argudas, which still highlights some of the critical issues.
